oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oral history interview with Marion F. "Sonny" Smith, 2007 September 25
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Marion F. "Sonny" Smith, conducted on 25 Sept. 2007 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Smith served with the 503rd Parachute Infantry Regiment of the 173rd Airborne Brigade (Separate) during the Vietnam War. Smith discusses his first jump training as a paratrooper; his arrival at Bien Hoa airbase in South Vietnam in 1966, where he witnessed American coffins being loaded on airplanes for shipment home; ambush training, including use of Claymore mines, booby traps, trip flares, and an anti-intrusion device; an incident when they were ambushed, a sergeant was shot during his effort to aid Smith, and the next group sent on patrol was named Operation Revenge in honor of the wounded sergeant; and an especially close call when his company was pinned down by a sniper in the jungle. The complete interview is available in the repository.
